instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used to predict loss of seed vigour in natural ageing (NA) seeds?
Output: To predict loss of seed vigour in natural ageing (NA) seeds,the researchers used visible spectrum and nir spectrum.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to predict loss of seed vigour in natural ageing (NA) seeds?
Output: Standard normal variate (SNV), autoscale (AS), and Savitzky–Golay first derivative (FD) with a smoothing gap of 9 and their combinations were used for spectral feature processing to predict loss of seed vigour in natural ageing (NA) seeds.

instruction: What metric was chosen to predict loss of seed vigour in natural ageing (NA) seeds and how far can this metric go?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the predictions of loss of seed vigour in natural ageing (NA) seeds is R2v-2. This metric measures the coefficient of determination for the external validation of the AA-based vigour prediction models on NA seeds. The R2v-2 value increased from 0.696 to 0.720 for Lvsechaoren and from 0.668 to 0.727 for Zhongtian 300 after removing the N-H bond-related wavebands. This indicates that the AA-based models achieved better performance on NA seeds with the improved R2v-2 values.

instruction: How were hyperspectral imaging and non-targeted metabolomics integrated in the related study to predict the loss of seed vigour in sweetcorn seeds undergoing natural ageing (NA)?
Output:
In the related study, hyperspectral imaging (HSI) and non-targeted metabolomics (LC-MS/MS) were integrated using PLS-R, SVM-R, and OPLS-DA. The researchers used HSI to capture spectral data from the sweetcorn seeds undergoing natural ageing (NA). This allowed them to analyze the patterns of spectral variation in the seeds. Additionally, non-targeted metabolomics analysis was performed using LC-MS/MS to identify differential metabolites in the seeds.

The integration of HSI and non-targeted metabolomics was done using multivariate analysis techniques such as PLS-R (Partial Least Squares Regression), SVM-R (Support Vector Machine Regression), and OPLS-DA (Orthogonal Partial Least Squares Discriminant Analysis). These techniques were used to build prediction models based on the data obtained from accelerated ageing (AA) studies. The models were then externally validated using independent AA and NA seed datasets.

By integrating HSI and non-targeted metabolomics, the researchers were able to identify discrepancies between the ageing mechanisms of AA and NA seeds. They found that certain N-H bond-related wavebands were interfering with the models' practicability.

instruction: Can the spectrum method used in this study be applied to predict the loss of seed vigour in sweetcorn seeds undergoing natural ageing (NA) based on data from accelerated ageing (AA) seeds?
Output:
No. Based on the information provided in the related study, the spectrum method used in the related study, which integrated hyperspectral imaging (HSI) and non-targeted metabolomics (LC-MS/MS) with machine learning algorithms, was initially developed and validated using data from accelerated ageing (AA) seeds. However, when applied to predict the loss of seed vigour in sweetcorn seeds undergoing natural ageing (NA), the precision of the predictions was found to be low (R2 & LE; 0.696). 

Therefore, based on the results presented in the related study, it can be concluded that the spectrum method used in this study may not be directly applicable to predict the loss of seed vigour in sweetcorn seeds undergoing natural ageing (NA) based on data from accelerated ageing (AA) seeds. Further modifications or adjustments may be necessary to improve the precision of the predictions for NA seeds.
